elements.text: I posted it on ProductHunt to see what's the experience like:

text: Interesting. I see in some of the other examples that you record direct manipulation actions on tables into a script. I’ve been experimenting with that too. How does that work for your users? Do they feel it is more “authentic” to write code like the pros do?

elements.text: Interesting. I see in some of the other examples that you record direct manipulation actions on tables into a script. I’ve been experimenting with that too. How does that work for your users? Do they feel it is more “authentic” to write code like the pros do?

text: our users are non programmers, some are sysadmins, some dbas, some managers, they use the manipulation to get the data to fit their needs, that's the part that gets the least complaints and observations (I guess that's a good thing?)

elements.text: our users are non programmers, some are sysadmins, some dbas, some managers, they use the manipulation to get the data to fit their needs, that's the part that gets the least complaints and observations (I guess that's a good thing?)

text: the parts that they ask more about that are related to programming are asset management (how do I upload an image and get a reference to it) and what we call "dictionaries" (mappings from keys to values that they can use across visualizations and dashboards and can change in one place to reflect in all places. They care a lot about a thing being the same color (and a specific color) across all dashboards.

elements.text: the parts that they ask more about that are related to programming are asset management (how do I upload an image and get a reference to it) and what we call "dictionaries" (mappings from keys to values that they can use across visualizations and dashboards and can change in one place to reflect in all places. They care a lot about a thing being the same color (and a specific color) across all dashboards.

text: After that they care a lot about adding interactivity (if the user clicks this, show that, filter this other thing, open another dashboard) this also brings the need to "override" configs (if user clicks a table row, open that dashboard but filter by this field in the row)

elements.text: After that they care a lot about adding interactivity (if the user clicks this, show that, filter this other thing, open another dashboard) this also brings the need to "override" configs (if user clicks a table row, open that dashboard but filter by this field in the row)

text: a long way to say that they care a lot about "configuration management" we provide a "chain" of dictionaries and lookup, there are dictionaries at the user level, then per dashboard, then per visualization, if you lookup key k1 in dict d1, it will look first in the visualization, then the dashboard, then the user, so you can start global and then specialize if needed per dashboard or visualization

elements.text: a long way to say that they care a lot about "configuration management" we provide a "chain" of dictionaries and lookup, there are dictionaries at the user level, then per dashboard, then per visualization, if you lookup key k1 in dict d1, it will look first in the visualization, then the dashboard, then the user, so you can start global and then specialize if needed per dashboard or visualization

text: they also care about adding lightweight interactivity, react to clicks to filter, overlay info or open other dashboards and visualizations

elements.text: they also care about adding lightweight interactivity, react to clicks to filter, overlay info or open other dashboards and visualizations

text: the programming part, the hardest is to undestand the iterator abstraction we use, I always go back and forth between "iterate by default a single item requrires explicit setup" and "single item by default, iteration requires explicit setup" (the one I'm using now)

elements.text: the programming part, the hardest is to undestand the iterator abstraction we use, I always go back and forth between "iterate by default a single item requrires explicit setup" and "single item by default, iteration requires explicit setup" (the one I'm using now)

text: one customer ask a lot about data provenance "show me how this data arrived here"

elements.text: one customer ask a lot about data provenance "show me how this data arrived here"

text: one pattern I've seen a lot is that they use the clone feature a lot, each customer has many dashboards that look similar, because when they see one they like or it looks like what they need, they clone it and change it for their needs. I guess that's also "programming by example" :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: one pattern I've seen a lot is that they use the clone feature a lot, each customer has many dashboards that look similar, because when they see one they like or it looks like what they need, they clone it and change it for their needs. I guess that's also "programming by example"

text: regarding "Do they feel it is more “authentic” to write code like the pros do?", I've never had a comment like that, maybe because it doesn't look like coding, so they don't expect it to feel closer to coding, manipulating data a small part of the tasks they do to share a dashboard, so maybe they see it as some advanced configuration thing? I may ask next week when I go to visit some of them

elements.text: regarding "Do they feel it is more “authentic” to write code like the pros do?", I've never had a comment like that, maybe because it doesn't look like coding, so they don't expect it to feel closer to coding, manipulating data a small part of the tasks they do to share a dashboard, so maybe they see it as some advanced configuration thing? I may ask next week when I go to visit some of them

text: what I've seen is some big data developers building throwaway dashboards to see preliminary result of jobs just because it's easy, one even made a small form and dashboard to gather some feedback from friends :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: what I've seen is some big data developers building throwaway dashboards to see preliminary result of jobs just because it's easy, one even made a small form and dashboard to gather some feedback from friends

text: one of our objectives is to make it so easy to gather, aggregate and visualize data that you will create throwaways on the spot because it's so easy

elements.text: one of our objectives is to make it so easy to gather, aggregate and visualize data that you will create throwaways on the spot because it's so easy

text:
The issue about authenticity comes up in end-user programming eg Scratch.

Do you see your competition as Jupyter/R notebooks or Tableau/BI tools?

elements.text:
The issue about authenticity comes up in end-user programming eg Scratch.

Do you see your competition as Jupyter/R notebooks or Tableau/BI tools?

text: every comparison is with BI tools, mostly Tableau and PowerBI, our customers haven't seen a lot of notebooks yet, we even introduce them on the big data side when they ask for "data science"

elements.text: every comparison is with BI tools, mostly Tableau and PowerBI, our customers haven't seen a lot of notebooks yet, we even introduce them on the big data side when they ask for "data science"

text: I guess it's easy to compare to BI tools because the results are "dashboards", we get resistance from the BI teams because they think we want to take their responsibilities or replace existing tools, we always end up fitting in the sysadmin side (I guess they are more pragmatic) or supported by management complaining about price, how long it takes to get a dashboard or the bottleneck on the BI team

elements.text: I guess it's easy to compare to BI tools because the results are "dashboards", we get resistance from the BI teams because they think we want to take their responsibilities or replace existing tools, we always end up fitting in the sysadmin side (I guess they are more pragmatic) or supported by management complaining about price, how long it takes to get a dashboard or the bottleneck on the BI team

text: the sharing and permission side seems to be appealing to them, we don't charge per "seat" or user, dashboards can be shared in many ways (public, public but password protected, only to authenticated users, or to specific users and/or groups), I'm not too familiar with the sharing aspects of other tools, but that seems to be a problem for them. They also push a lot for "curation", to share a list of dashboards for a particular user, use case or problem. We are slowly becoming a social network :stuck_out_tongue:

elements.text: the sharing and permission side seems to be appealing to them, we don't charge per "seat" or user, dashboards can be shared in many ways (public, public but password protected, only to authenticated users, or to specific users and/or groups), I'm not too familiar with the sharing aspects of other tools, but that seems to be a problem for them. They also push a lot for "curation", to share a list of dashboards for a particular user, use case or problem. We are slowly becoming a social network

text: we jokingly referred to this version as "facebook but for data analysis" and it seems there's something there because most of the feedback is from the sharing results side than from the coding side

elements.text: we jokingly referred to this version as "facebook but for data analysis" and it seems there's something there because most of the feedback is from the sharing results side than from the coding side

text: some also like the fact that the shared thing is still interactive, user can live filter search style and edit advanced filters with the formula editor. Also they love that each chart can export the underlying data to excel

elements.text: some also like the fact that the shared thing is still interactive, user can live filter search style and edit advanced filters with the formula editor. Also they love that each chart can export the underlying data to excel

text: (having the escape hatch seems to be important, don't know how often they use it)

elements.text: (having the escape hatch seems to be important, don't know how often they use it)

text: I may try a more "notebook" style for the next version, changes in place confuse a little and then I need to add tracing and time traveling to show intermediate values, next version may be just a sequence of operations where each can expand to show the value after the operation like notebooks or collapse it to only see the input and the output

elements.text: I may try a more "notebook" style for the next version, changes in place confuse a little and then I need to add tracing and time traveling to show intermediate values, next version may be just a sequence of operations where each can expand to show the value after the operation like notebooks or collapse it to only see the input and the output

text: I’m also concerned about those issues. Did you see my last demo? <https://vimeo.com/274771188>

attachments.title: Direct Programming
attachments.text:
To make programming more accessible to regular people it may help to make it less abstract and more concrete. Towards that end I am taking another run at the old ideas of macro recording and Programming by Example. Many such efforts abstracted user actions into conventional code. Instead I co-design the PL and UI to be analogous, so that programs and users have much the same capabilities, and programs look much like recorded transcripts of user actions. Conscientiously following this design principle leads in the opposite direction of current PL trends, towards a deeply imperative semantics and a de-emphasis of functional abstraction.

Any attempt to make programming more concrete faces two challenges: loops and conditionals, for they necessarily deal with hypothetical situations. My approach is to extend the direct manipulation metaphor onto _template_ states that prototype iteration, and _example_ states that witness alternative cases.

text: Cool! Having other people criticize and improve upon my work is a sign of success.

elements.text: Cool! Having other people criticize and improve upon my work is a sign of success.

text: it was not meant as a critique, just a comparison to have some sort of discussion, I've heard research people say that papers are a long term discussion between different researchers, since I prefer demos (and it seems you too), I thought that a reply trying to show a different approach under the same structure and topics would be interesting, still thinking on how to structure long term discussions between projects of this sort, I like <@U5TCAFTD3> idea of having a fixed set of problems to solve with different tools and see what works, what doesn't, what's easy and what's hard, but my tool being a stream processing/aggregation thing is not well suited to implement a todo list :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: it was not meant as a critique, just a comparison to have some sort of discussion, I've heard research people say that papers are a long term discussion between different researchers, since I prefer demos (and it seems you too), I thought that a reply trying to show a different approach under the same structure and topics would be interesting, still thinking on how to structure long term discussions between projects of this sort, I like

idea of having a fixed set of problems to solve with different tools and see what works, what doesn't, what's easy and what's hard, but my tool being a stream processing/aggregation thing is not well suited to implement a todo list

text: the main difference is kind of fundamental, your tool understand types, so a collection has a type for the items, then you can show a "schema" of the item to operate on it as an explicit way to say "over all values of this shape", in my case since the inputs are schemaless the most I can do is infer the schema but I haven't done that yet, that's why I have the explicit iterator value, which is better than explicit imperative loops but next time I may go with "iteration by default, single item is a special case", something I've been exploring a little with the idea of an path item that represents a "column", that is, all items with that key in a colection, the column explicitly applies to all items and if used in a value context will work as a generator for that column (will generate a list of values for that field in the collection)

elements.text: the main difference is kind of fundamental, your tool understand types, so a collection has a type for the items, then you can show a "schema" of the item to operate on it as an explicit way to say "over all values of this shape", in my case since the inputs are schemaless the most I can do is infer the schema but I haven't done that yet, that's why I have the explicit iterator value, which is better than explicit imperative loops but next time I may go with "iteration by default, single item is a special case", something I've been exploring a little with the idea of an path item that represents a "column", that is, all items with that key in a colection, the column explicitly applies to all items and if used in a value context will work as a generator for that column (will generate a list of values for that field in the collection)

text: Thanks for sharing.  I was doing this sort of filter thing all day – both in Excel and Numbers.  Two observations...

elements.text: Thanks for sharing.  I was doing this sort of filter thing all day – both in Excel and Numbers.  Two observations...

text: Small observation: you can assume an OR if someone drags two cells from the same column into the query.

elements.text: Small observation: you can assume an OR if someone drags two cells from the same column into the query.

text: Big observation: I've played with some cool ideas with a notebook style for these kinds of operations.  It can work really well.  One view is to show data, operation, data, operation.  It's like a command-line transcript, but structured rather than text.  The other is more like a traditional GUI where you manipulate an object in place.  You can imagine this as stacking transformations.  Then switching between these views is just a matter of rotation.  From there you can go wild.  One natural path is to allow for branching and merging.  (In the context of tables, merging nodes often correspond to joins.)  If you aren't careful you find yourself in parametric modeling node-and-edges land.  I don't know if madness is the final destination, but at least you end up with a kind space of interaction modalities in which familiar conventions are projections.

elements.text: Big observation: I've played with some cool ideas with a notebook style for these kinds of operations.  It can work really well.  One view is to show data, operation, data, operation. You can imagine this as stacking transformations.  Then switching between these views is just a matter of rotation.  From there you can go wild.  One natural path is to allow for branching and merging.  (In the context of tables, merging nodes often correspond to joins.)  If you aren't careful you find yourself in parametric modeling node-and-edges land.  I don't know if madness is the final destination, but at least you end up with a kind space of interaction modalities in which familiar conventions are projections.
